text: New Zealand Mathematical Olympiad Committee Now observe that ABD and ADE have the same base AD, and the same area, so they too must have the same altitude. In addition, E must be on the opposite side of AD to B, since ABCDE is convex. Considering now the triangles BCD and BCE, we see that they have the same base BC, but the altitude of BCE is twice that of BCD. It follows that it has twice the area, as claimed.
